citations.narrative:
The enclosure housing the three emus does not currently have security measures that contain all birds securely such as
safety doors, double door entry/exit doors or other equivalent systems. There is only a single gate entry between the
enclosure and the large unfenced property.
The security measures are necessary to help prevent escape of the birds while the enclosure doors are opened and
closed. The facility shall ensure that all bird enclosures have security measures such as safety doors, double door
entry/exit doors or other equivalent systems.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The current program of veterinary care needs to be reviewed with the attending veterinarian to ensure that adequate
veterinary care is being provided. The current program provides for the use of a 'bullet' as an option for euthanasia but
does not describe how that would be done to ensure rapid unconsciousness and subsequent death without evidence of
pain or distress. In addition, the current program includes the use of 'injectable ivermectin' for parasite prevention for the
arctic foxes but does not adequately describe the route or dosage that the ivermectin is to be administered. Adequate and
complete programs of veterinary care are necessary to protect the health of the animals. The facility shall establish and
maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose
and treat diseases and injuries.

The two primary enclosures each housing one arctic fox kit are currently located behind the house but are not enclosed
within a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. A perimeter fence is
necessary to protect the animals by functioning as a secondary containment system and by restricting animals and
unauthorized persons from having contact with the fox kits. The facility shall ensure that the primary enclosures for the
arctic foxes are enclosed within a perimeter fence that is at a minimum six feet high and three feet away from the primary
enclosures.

The area between the African crested porcupine enclosure and the wallaby enclosure (approximately 3ftx9ft) contains in
its entirety several planted bamboo plants along with an overgrowth of weeds. Weeds may harbor parasites and pests
such as ticks and mice that may affect the animals. The grounds shall be kept in good repair with weeds removed to
protect the animals and facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices.

The floor of the primary enclosure housing the red golden pheasant is dirt over a buried wire fencing material. There is a
hole that was dug by a previous animal that is several inches deep exposing the wire and leaving a large hole. The bird
may injure itself if it accidentally steps into the deep opening.
The facility shall ensure that the flooring is constructed and maintained in a manner that protects the birds’ feet and legs
from injury.
This is a1st re-license inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
Applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by 60 days from 31Jul2024 or the Applicant will forfeit the
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply.
Please contact your inspector to schedule your next licensing inspection.
Regulated activity can continue for the number/group of animals already authorized under your existing USDA license
until it expires. Conducting regulated activity without a valid USDA license, to include animal numbers above the approved
maximum or with an animal group that is not currently authorized, is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
n

narrative:
3.150(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The enclosure housing the three emus does not currently have security measures that contain all birds securely such as 
safety doors, double door entry/exit doors or other equivalent systems. There is only a single gate entry between the 
enclosure and the large unfenced property.  
The security measures are necessary to help prevent escape of the birds while the enclosure doors are opened and 
closed. The facility shall ensure that all bird enclosures have security measures such as safety doors, double door 
entry/exit doors or other equivalent systems. 
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The current program of veterinary care needs to be reviewed with the attending veterinarian to ensure that adequate 
veterinary care is being provided. The current program provides for the use of a 'bullet' as an option for euthanasia but 
does not describe how that would be done to ensure rapid unconsciousness and subsequent death without evidence of 
pain or distress. In addition, the current program includes the use of 'injectable ivermectin' for parasite prevention for the 
arctic foxes but does not adequately describe the route or dosage that the ivermectin is to be administered. Adequate and 
complete programs of veterinary care are necessary to protect the health of the animals. The facility shall establish and 
maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose 
and treat diseases and injuries. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The two primary enclosures each housing one arctic fox kit are currently located behind the house but are not enclosed 
within a perimeter fence that is of sufficient height to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. A perimeter fence is 
necessary to protect the animals by functioning as a secondary containment system and by restricting animals and 
unauthorized persons from having contact with the fox kits. The facility shall ensure that the primary enclosures for the 
arctic foxes are enclosed within a perimeter fence that is at a minimum six feet high and three feet away from the primary 
enclosures. 
3.131(c)

Sanitation. 
The area between the African crested porcupine enclosure and the wallaby enclosure (approximately 3ftx9ft) contains in 
its entirety several planted bamboo plants along with an overgrowth of weeds. Weeds may harbor parasites and pests 
such as ticks and mice that may affect the animals. The grounds shall be kept in good repair with weeds removed to 
protect the animals and facilitate the prescribed husbandry practices. 
3.153(a)(1)(x) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
The floor of the primary enclosure housing the red golden pheasant is dirt over a buried wire fencing material. There is a 
hole that was dug by a previous animal that is several inches deep exposing the wire and leaving a large hole. The bird 
may injure itself if it accidentally steps into the deep opening.  
The facility shall ensure that the flooring is constructed and maintained in a manner that protects the birds’ feet and legs 
from injury. 
 
This is a1st re-license inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
Applicant. 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by 60 days from 31Jul2024 or the Applicant will forfeit the 
license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. 
Please contact your inspector to schedule your next licensing inspection. 
Regulated activity can continue for the number/group of animals already authorized under your existing USDA license 
until it expires. Conducting regulated activity without a valid USDA license, to include animal numbers above the approved 
maximum or with an animal group that is not currently authorized, is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
